case_vignette: A 53-year-old farmer presents to the clinic for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on his arm. He states that he first noticed the lesion last year, but he believes that it has been slowly growing in size. He otherwise does not have any complaints and is generally healthy.
question: Which  findings on physical exam would suggest a malignant diagnosis?

trial_1.vignette_frq: Physical exam findings that would suggest a malignant diagnosis include asymmetry, irregular borders, uneven color, and a change in size or shape over time.
trial_1.summarized_frq:
Physical exam findings that would suggest a malignant diagnosis include: 
- Irregular borders or shape of the lesion
- Asymmetry of the lesion
- Variable color or texture of the lesion
- Ulceration or bleeding
- Rapid growth or expansion of the lesion
- Lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes)
- Skin thickening or firmness in the surrounding area
- Dysplasia or abnormal cells on the surface of the lesion.

trial_2.summarized_frq:
Physical exam findings that suggest a malignant diagnosis include: 
- Rapid growth of the spot
- Irregular borders or shape of the spot
- Changes in the texture or appearance of the skin around the spot
- Changes in the color of the skin around the spot
- Ulceration or bleeding from the spot
- Lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes)
- Skin thickening or firmness in the affected area
- Pain or discomfort in the affected area
- Rapid onset of symptoms
It is important to note that these findings do not necessarily indicate a malignant diagnosis, and further testing such as a biopsy may be necessary to confirm a diagnosis.
